content.raw:
This test could be flaky. It relies on staging-api.ignitionfuel.org, which is not guaranteed to be stable.

The test has passed in subsequent pipelines:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/239
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/240

content.raw:
Now looking at the reports, I realized the main reason is that codecov [is not counting partially hit lines](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/about-code-coverage) for coverage. See for example how [ClentConfig.cc](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/src/21b8d3ebcce0113580e9246c5547d4533e029519/src/ClientConfig.cc) has only 40% coverage.

There is an [open issue](https://github.com/codecov/support/issues/193) on codecov about this.
content.html:
Now looking at the reports, I realized the main reason is that codecov is not counting partially hit lines for coverage. See for example how ClentConfig.cc has only 40% coverage.

There is an open issue on codecov about this.

content.html: Thanks for digging into that.

content.raw:
Is it because it doesn't have `Set`? This seems to be the pattern all over this repository, I'd vote for leaving it as is and changing `SetUserAgent` to follow the current pattern. It's important to be consistent and it would be a huge effort to start deprecating the whole API.

~~~
$ grep -r ":Set" src/
src/Zip_TEST.cc:      return ::SetCurrentDirectoryA(_newTempPath.c_str()) != 0;
src/REST.cc:void REST::SetUserAgent(const std::string &_agent)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ServerConfig::SetAPIKey(const std::string &_key)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ClientConfig::SetConfigPath(const std::string &_path)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ClientConfig::SetUserAgent(const std::string &_agent)
~~~
content.html:
Is it because it doesn't have Set? This seems to be the pattern all over this repository, I'd vote for leaving it as is and changing SetUserAgent to follow the current pattern. It's important to be consistent and it would be a huge effort to start deprecating the whole API.

$ grep -r ":Set" src/
src/Zip_TEST.cc:      return ::SetCurrentDirectoryA(_newTempPath.c_str()) != 0;
src/REST.cc:void REST::SetUserAgent(const std::string &_agent)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ServerConfig::SetAPIKey(const std::string &_key)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ClientConfig::SetConfigPath(const std::string &_path)
src/ClientConfig.cc:void ClientConfig::SetUserAgent(const std::string &_agent)

content.raw: The lack of Set breaks our style. Consistency across the libraries is important, and this library is an outlier that needs to be fixed.
content.html: The lack of Set breaks our style. Consistency across the libraries is important, and this library is an outlier that needs to be fixed.

content.raw:
I see this pattern pretty often on ign-math, do we have it explicitly mentioned on the style guide?

If we're going to change it, I suggest we trace a plan for it, it feels a bit out of place to change only one function on this pull request. What do you think?
content.html:
I see this pattern pretty often on ign-math, do we have it explicitly mentioned on the style guide?

If we're going to change it, I suggest we trace a plan for it, it feels a bit out of place to change only one function on this pull request. What do you think?

content.raw:
ping @nkoenig 

I see a lot of new PRs changing style on this repo. Did you have a chance to look at ign-math? Is the idea to also change the style there?
content.html:
ping @nkoenig

I see a lot of new PRs changing style on this repo. Did you have a chance to look at ign-math? Is the idea to also change the style there?

content.raw: I don't have immediate plans to change the style anywhere else. I was here, so I updated the style. No need to make explicit plans to update style elsewhere.
content.html: I don't have immediate plans to change the style anywhere else. I was here, so I updated the style. No need to make explicit plans to update style elsewhere.

content.raw:
Ok I see.

I agree with @sloretz that rules like these should be explicit in the style guide; I also didn't know this was a rule, and I suspect no one else who has worked on this repo and approved the current code knew it either - otherwise we would have fixed it. Based on the fact that the present style is actually found on other Ignition projects, "setters must be prefixed by Set" sounds like a new rule to me.

I'd like to point out that it can be quite cumbersome for downstream projects to handle tick-tock deprecation. Making the rules clear upfront to the whole team would decrease the number of times we go through deprecation cycles because of style, thus decreasing the barrier to adoption of our libraries.
content.html:
Ok I see.

I agree with @sloretz that rules like these should be explicit in the style guide; I also didn't know this was a rule, and I suspect no one else who has worked on this repo and approved the current code knew it either - otherwise we would have fixed it. Based on the fact that the present style is actually found on other Ignition projects, "setters must be prefixed by Set" sounds like a new rule to me.

I'd like to point out that it can be quite cumbersome for downstream projects to handle tick-tock deprecation. Making the rules clear upfront to the whole team would decrease the number of times we go through deprecation cycles because of style, thus decreasing the barrier to adoption of our libraries.

content.raw:
It's my understanding that the "setters must be prefixed by Set" is not a new rule. This topic was discussed in-depth last year, but was not formally written down. I'll take a look at the style guide updates started by Shane shortly.

Yes, any API changes incur a cost. That cost does not outweigh the cost of an inconsistent API. We also shouldn't stop API changes because it'll affect users. The tick-tock model is designed to facilitate API changes, not block them. 

I don't believe deprecation cycles decrease library adoption. A cumbersome API would, as well as a lack of documentation and feature set.
content.html:
It's my understanding that the "setters must be prefixed by Set" is not a new rule. This topic was discussed in-depth last year, but was not formally written down. I'll take a look at the style guide updates started by Shane shortly.

Yes, any API changes incur a cost. That cost does not outweigh the cost of an inconsistent API. We also shouldn't stop API changes because it'll affect users. The tick-tock model is designed to facilitate API changes, not block them.

I don't believe deprecation cycles decrease library adoption. A cumbersome API would, as well as a lack of documentation and feature set.
